text: Situation A. Comparing Sample and Population Distributions
How does your sample distribution in the Initial Challenge compare to the distribution of the whole population?

Answers will vary. Many samples will closely resemble the population. Some samples will show variations. You can look at the various samples that are drawn by your class and use the actual data as a point of reference.
Situation B. The Size of Random Samples

Cassie’s class wondered about the size of random samples. Each of the 30 students in the class found a random sample of 5 students, 10 students, and 30 students. They calculated the median for each sample. Cassie’s class created line plots of the medians for each sample size.

1. What patterns do you see for the three different distributions?
  2. Suppose each student in your class chose a sample of 50 students and found the means and medians of the data for the number of hours slept. What would you expect the line plots of these means and medians to look like? Explain.

1. As the size of the random sample increases, the medians of the random samples are more dense around the value of 8 hours. 8 hours of sleep was the median in the population data.
  2. Given evidence from samples of 5, 10, and 30 students, we would expect that medians for samples of 50 students would show greater increase of occurrence.
